StoryText: Strong! I can now do the monkey bars, all the way to the end! I'm so proud; I want to show %FirstName:NPC:1%... But %FirstName:NPC:1% can't do them, he gets puffed and has to drop down at the end.
Question: Should I show him what I can do or not?

OptionText.Text: Yes, do the monkey bars. He's my friend, he'll be happy for me!
Help him get the 'hang' of it!
Don't show him. Play something else.

OptionResult.Result: I don't know whether he was jealous or just annoyed with himself, but %FirstName:NPC:1% got moody. He didn't congratulate me or anything. We kind of fell out.
OptionResult.DiaryEntry: I suppose you shouldn't show off what you can do, or you should just be more careful about it. I could do the monkey bars, but %FirstName:NPC:1% couldn't, and didn't appreciate me showing him how it was done.

OptionResult.Result: %FirstName:NPC:1% was so chuffed when I offered to help him with the monkey bars, and all he needed was a little lift. I got a chance to demonstrate too, and he high fived me!
OptionResult.DiaryEntry: I helped %FirstName:NPC:1% with his monkey bar skills. I love hanging with my mates!

OptionResult.Result: %FirstName:NPC:1% and I had a funny game of doctors and nurses, and left the park tired and still friends. I wished I could've shown him the monkey bars, but I guess I saved his feelings.
OptionResult.DiaryEntry: Is it always good to be modest? Sometimes I think it's important to show people what you can do! I guess I spared %FirstName:NPC:1%'s feelings, but so what if I can do the monkey bars and he can't!
